thread.title: Eagles lose to Panthers: Good, bad and ugly from 27-16 defeat
thread.title_full: Eagles lose to Panthers: Good, bad and ugly from 27-16 defeat | NJ.com

author: Matt Lombardo | For NJ Advance Media
title: Eagles lose to Panthers: Good, bad and ugly from 27-16 defeat
text:
It is fitting that the competitive portion the Eagles ' loss to the Carolina Panthers on Sunday night came to an end with a well-thrown Sam Bradford pass sailing through the hands of Miles Austin.
Eagles wide receivers struggled with drops, including one by Josh Huff in the end zone and several more by wide receiver Jordan Matthews and tight end Zach Ertz as the Eagles fell to 3-4 and second place in the NFC East.
The Panthers, now 6-0, remained unbeaten.
Eagles quarterback Sam Bradford was inconsistent once again and except for a 63-yard rushing touchdown from running back Ryan Mathews, the offense lacked a big-play punch necessary to win.
Despite running more plays (81-58) and winning the time of possession battle (31:06 to 28:04) against the Carolina Panthers, the Eagles came up short.
WATCH: Cam Newton tries to draw penalty with Oscar-worthy flop
Here are some instant takeaways from Sunday night's loss:
GOOD:
The more plays the better: Eagles head coach Chip Kelly doesn't care much about winning the time of possession battle. Rather, he believes total plays have a significant impact on the outcome. The Eagles offense runs at its most efficient when the Eagles run more plays than the opponent, largely because of the cumulative impact those plays have on a defense. But Sunday, that formula didn't work.
Ryan Mathews strikes again: With the Eagles trailing 21-6 with 9:33 remaining in the third quarter, Mathews' 63-yard touchdown run was just what the offense needed after struggling to move the chains. Mathew finished with six carries for 97 yards and one touchdown while averaging 16.2 yards per rush.
Welcome aboard, Byron Maxwell: Among the three Cam Newton interceptions forced by the Eagles was Byron Maxwell's first since signing a $63 million contract over the offseason. Maxwell was at the right place at the right time to catch a ball that bounced off of Panthers' receiver Devin Funchess.
BAD:
Jason Peters injures his back: Seven-time Pro Bowl left tackle Jason Peters was carted off in the first quarter with a lower-back injury. Just as the offensive line finally had been developing some cohesion in recent weeks, which translated to improved play, Peters injury comes at the worst possible time. It's been a tough season for Peters, who has spent plenty of time on the ground or on the bench due to minor injuries through the first seven games.
Penalties are becoming a trend: One week after committing two penalties against the Giants, the Eagles offensive line added four more, including a Jason Kelce holding call and two penalties on stalwart right tackle Lane Johnson. As if dropped passes weren't costly enough, penalties have played a key factor in the Eagles' offense's inability to establish consistent momentum.
UGLY:
Drops are the new normal for Jordan Matthews: After seven games, Matthews has at least six drops, including two against the Panthers. The first of Matthews' drops Sunday night came in the first quarter and was intercepted in a similar fashion to the game-ending interception against the Atlanta Falcons on opening night. On the second drop, the ball him in the hands on what would have been a third-down conversion.
